Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to study the Gromov-Witten invariants of symplectic 4-manifolds, with special attention to Kahler surfaces. It consists of three projects. The PI (with Thomas H. Parker) showed that the GW theory of Kahler surfaces (with a smooth canonical divisor) can be reduced to the local GW theory of spin curves. The PI also showed that the local GW theory can be reduced to the dimension zero relative local GW theory. The goal of the first two projects (with Thomas H. Parker) is to completely describe the dimension zero relative local GW theory of spin curves. This will give a complete calculation of the GW invariants of Kahler surfaces (with a smooth canonical divisor). The goal of the third project is to extend aspects of a structure theorem for the GW invariants of Kahler surfaces to general symplectic 4-manifolds. This extension will provide a suitable notion of the number of the components of the canonical class which is a very important symplectic invariant for the topology of symplectic 4-manifolds. The extension will also remove the smoothness condition of canonical divisor in the previous projects.

In recent years, some long-standing mathematics problems have been solved using the newly-developed theory of GW invariants. This theory provides an innovative method for counting certain fundamental geometric objects called holomorphic curves. The resulting counts, and the systematic methods for calculating them, have spurred significant advances in two classical fields of mathematics: symplectic geometry and enumerative geometry. The GW invariants also play an important role bridging mathematics and theoretical physics. This project seeks to develop new geometric techniques for calculating GW invariants using methods in partial differential equations, topology and algebraic geometry. The techniques and ideas developed in this project should be very useful in other contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Gromov-Witten theory provides an innovative method for counting certain fundamental geometric objects. The resulting counts are GW invariant; in general, it is very difficult to compute them. GW invariants and the development of techniques for calculating them have spurred significant advances in several areas in mathematics, especially in symplectic topology and algebraic geometry.  

This project was aimed at developing new geometric methods for computation of GW invariants and was based on the PI’s work with Thomas H. Parker which is a remarkable structure theorem linking the GW theory of (general) Kähler surfaces to the GW theory of curves. The main goals of the project were:

  1. To calculate the spin Hurwitz numbers that give the dimension zero GW invariants of Kähler surfaces.
  2. To show that the GW theory of Kähler surfaces is completely determined by the spin Hurwitz numbers and by certain twisted GW invariants of curves.
  3. To extend aspects of a structure of the GW theory of a Kähler surfaces to a general symplectic 4-manifolds.

The first goal was completed, and substantial progress on the second goal was made. With Parker, the PI obtained a degeneration formula for spin Hurwitz numbers. The PI then used the degeneration formula to directly construct a 2-dimensional Topological Quantum Field Theory (TQFT) that gives a combinatorial formula for spin Hurwitz numbers; Gunningham first proved this formula by constructing an extended TQFT. The degeneration formula naturally suggests an appropriate limit obstruction bundle (under degeneration) that determines the twisted invariants in the second goal. Observing some symmetry of the twisted invariants, the PI obtained a conjectural closed formula for GW invariants of Kähler surfaces. Its proof will complete the second goal and will shed light on the third goal. The ideas and approaches in the outcomes of this project should be very useful in other contexts.

The PI’s research and activities impacts the education of mathematics. Since the PI joined the mathematics Department at University of Central Florida, he has developed new graduate courses for geometry and topology and has ran geometry learning seminars. He has also been actively working to enhance the quality of the undergraduate mathematics program.
